Crime_Name: Predatory Pricing and Unlawful Interference with Economic Interests
Legal_Issue: Whether free online exam guides constituted predatory pricing or unlawful interference with economic interests
Evidence_Assessment: No proof of intent to harm competition or causation of plaintiff's losses; multiple factors affected sales decline
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove predatory pricing or unlawful interference
Legal_Rule: Predatory pricing involves selling at unreasonably low prices to eliminate competitors; unlawful interference requires interference with trade, unlawful means, intent to injure, and actual injury
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendants' free exams reduced plaintiff's sales, violating the Competition Act
Key_Evidence_Considered: Defendants offered free online exams as marketing tool; no evidence of anti-competitive intent or direct causation
Legal_Framework: Competition law, Tort of unlawful interference with economic interests
Defendant_Response: Free exams were a legitimate marketing strategy, not intended to harm competition
Remedy_Requested: Legal remedy for alleged violation of Competition Act
Outcome: Defendants did not violate the Competition Act
Remedy_Sought: Compensation or injunction for unfair competition
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Competition Act relating to predatory pricing; common law on unlawful interference
Legal_Provision_Cited: Competition Act provisions on predatory pricing
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to establish essential elements of the claims
Governing_Rule: Competition Act and common law principles on economic torts
